Graphical abstract In the as-designed core–shell 0.2Pt/Y@nS catalyst, the distance between the acid sites and metal sites can be adjusted in the range of a nanoscale, a clear and definite of mass transfer from metal to acid, and to metal can play a role in controlling the reaction process. Owing to the important industrial value in hydro-isomerization/-cracking process, metal–acid bifunctional catalysts have attracted much attention. However, exploring the spatial distance namely the intimacy between the two active components remains a primary challenge in the development of a bifunctional catalytic system, as there are limited synthesis protocols for rationally organizing the two components to maximize the synergistic effect. Herein, a series of catalysts with different degrees of intimacy were prepared, which can be assorted into four scales: atomic-, nanometer-, µm-, and millimeter-scale. Specially, Pt/Y@nS core–shell composite with an adjustable shell thickness in a nanometer scale (∼15 to ∼ 60 nm) was designed and synthesized. Not only playing a crucial role in confining and promoting highly dispersed Pt nanoparticles, the acid-free mesoporous SiO2 shell also finely regulates the distance (“L”) between acids and metals in a nanoscale, thereby facilitating a deep investigation into the spatial relationship between metals and acid sites. Three n-alkanes (n-heptane, n-dodecane, and n-hexadecane) with a different molecular chain length (“l”) were selected as probe molecules so as to investigate the effect of “L/l” ratio on the hydro-isomerization/-cracking reaction. The results indicated that a relatively small L/l (≤13.1) ratio is not in favor of the conversion of the alkane molecules, for example, the hydro-cracking/-isomerization process of n-dodecane, n-hexadecane, or n-heptane on 0.2Pt/Y, 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S. A smaller L/l ratio offers the catalyst with a low catalytic activity, here, isomerization and cracking yields are low. High selectivity towards mono-branched i-alkane accompanied with a little of cracked products with more carbon atoms can be obtained. On the contrary, a relatively large L/l (52.3 > L/l ≥ 26.5) ratio in the catalyst contributes to elevating the catalytic activity, for example, the hydro-cracking/-isomerization process of n-dodecane or n-hexadecane on catalysts 0.2Pt/Y@1.5S, n-heptane on 0.2Pt/Y@1S. A larger L/l ratio gives the catalyst a higher activity in hydrocracking, in which more cleavage products with lesser carbon atoms can be obtained, and with an enhanced L/l ratio, the selectivity towards corresponding i-alkane along with the selectivity ratio of mono-branched i-alkanes to multi-branched ones in the final products decreases significantly. Keywords Hydro-isomerization/-cracking Intimacy Bifunctional catalysts Core-shell structure Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Bifunctional catalysts play crucial roles in hydro-isomerization/-cracking of n-alkanes, which aims to produce high octane gasoline, high-quality lubricant base oils, and high-grade diesel fuel, or to improve the fuel quality in petroleum refining industry or in renewable hydrocarbon processing and so on [1,2]. For the hydroisomerization process, it promotes the conversion of straight-chain alkanes into corresponding branched-chain ones, which contributes to significantly lowering the freezing point and enhancing the low-temperature fluidity properties of intermediate fractions, particularly those derived from Fischer–Tropsch (F–T) synthesis and biomass processing [2,3]. Typical bifunctional catalyst contains metal sites and acid sites, which are widely acknowledged to significantly contribute to achieving the desired controlled product distribution and effectively enhancing reaction activity [4]. Where, the metal centers promote alkane activation, dehydrogenation, and hydrogenation, while the acidic centers facilitate C–C bond cleavage and isomerization processes [5,6]. As a familiar donor of acid sites in bifunctional catalyst, zeolite has an abundant porous system, adjustable acidity, and excellent thermal/hydrothermal stability, and is responsible for alkene protonation and subsequent isomerization and cracking [7,8]. The Brønsted acid sites generated by the charge imbalance for the zeolite framework promote isomerization and cracking processes via carbenium ion rearrangement. Meanwhile, zeolite possesses highly ordered microporous structure (with a diameter of less than 2 nm) that closely matches the kinetic diameter of hydrocarbon molecules. When the kinetic diameter of a guest molecule approaches the size of these microporous channels, it leads to a significant diffusion limitation [8]. Recently, many studies have been carried out to investigate the effects of zeolite texture and acidity on the hydroisomerization of n-alkanes with more than six carbon atoms over metal-loading ZSM-5, ZSM-22, Beta, Y, mordenite, SAPO-11 catalysts etc [2,9–16]. Among these zeolites, Y zeolite possesses three-dimensional channels containing 12-membered rings (0.74 nm × 0.74 nm) and “super-cage” structures, which could minimize the diffusion limitation for branched paraffin isomers within the channel [17,18], thus resulting in higher yields at increased conversion rates compared with Pt NPs supported on mono-dimensional large pore zeolites such as MOR [19], tridimensional medium zeolites like MFI [16,20], and one-dimensional medium zeolites such as TON [15,21,22]. As an engine for stimulating the dehydrogenation or hydrogenation process, metal centers can not only lead to the formation of alkenes [12], but also transform the generated intermediate olefins into corresponding alkane. As a key component in the bifunctional catalysts, metals have a great influence on catalytic activity owing to the differences in particle size and intrinsic dehydrogenation activity [23]. It is generally accepted that as compared with non-noble metals (such as Ni), catalysts containing noble metals (such as Pt and Pd) exhibit a superior activity and demonstrate a better suitability in processes such as hydrocracking and processing of sulphur-free feedstocks [24,25]. Where, platinum, as a heavy element with significant atomic volume and polarizability, exhibits favorable van der Waals interactions when in contact with the pore walls of zeolite. Compared with non-noble metals that require a higher loading amount, Pt usually exists in less than 1 wt% in hydroisomerization catalyst [25,26] and is more easily loaded on zeolite in the form of tiny Pt NPs [24]. When referring to bifunctional catalysts, two catalytic functions are required: one is the hydrogen/dehydrogenation (on metal) function, and the other is the isomerizationan/cracking (on acid) function. Dehydrogenation of n-alkane occurs on the metal site, followed by protonation of alkenes generated on the zeolite Brønsted acid sites [27–29]. Then, the isomerous olefinic products are hydrogenated on the metallic phase and desorbed from the catalyst. The combination of two types of active center in a single reactor can lead to an exceptional functionality, as a catalyst with only one function cannot achieve the synergistic effect required for a cascade reaction [30]. In order to attain an optimal activity and achieve a maximum isomerization selectivity, an impeccable bifunctional catalyst should possess a well-balanced carrier-acid functionality as well as dehydrogenation/hydrogenation functionality. Exploring the spatial distance or intimacy [31–36] between the two well-matched active components is a primary challenge in developing a well bifunctional catalytic system. The classic bifunctional catalytic scheme, especially the hydro-isomerization/-cracking of n-alkanes, has been established for more than 50 years [33,34]. Weisz's intimacy criterion [33] has dictated the maximum distance between the two types of active site, beyond which catalytic activity decreases. Owing to the lack of nano-precision synthesis and characterization methods, the intimacy criteria have long been unexplored in-depth and are often interpreted simply as “the closer the better” for locating metal and acid sites [35]. Zecevic et al. [35] found that loading Pt NPs inside zeolite micropores to maintain the closest intimacy with acid sites does not deliver optimal performance in terms of high quality diesel production, as it increases the residence time of reactant molecules with acid and metal active species and potentially enhances side reactions to some extent. This aforementioned contradiction emphasizes the importance of determining the optimal proximity for these two active sites and comprehending the relationship between distance and catalytic performance. It also implies that maintaining a harmoniously balanced distance between metal and acid sites is crucial for the successful design of bifunctional catalysis [17,36–39]. Owing to limited control over this parameter during catalyst synthesis, there have been only a few investigations on the required intimacy between the two types of active site in bifunctional applications. The present work aims to develop a “three birds with one stone” original strategy for designing and preparing Y@nSiO2 composite with a core–shell structure by in-situ growth of an adjustable mesoporous SiO2 shell on the surface of Y crystals: (1) The intimacy between the zeolite acid sites and metal centers could be finely regulated within a nanoscale range by controlling the thickness of the shell layer mesoporous SiO2 (negligible acidity); (2) Mesoporous SiO2 could serve as an express way that accelerates the diffusion of large molecules; (3) The mesoporous SiO2 shell layer could also provide well-ordered mesoporous channels that confine and promote highly dispersed Pt nanoparticles, thereby facilitating investigations into the spatial relationship between metals and acid sites in nanometer-scale. The intimacy of active sites could be divided into four distinct scales: atomic-, nanometer-, µm-, and millimeter-scale (Scheme 1 ). Atomic-, micro-, and millimeter-scale are obtained by the physical mixture of Pt/Y and SiO2, Y and Pt/SiO2, and dual-bed of Y and Pt/SiO2 layers, respectively. Further, bifunctional core–shell catalysts composed of Y, SiO2 and Pt NPs are designed to control the distance meticulously between the two active sites by modulating the shell thickness. n-Dodecane, n-hexadecane, and n-heptane are chosen as probe molecules with different molecule chain length to investigate the catalytic properties of these catalysts. The detailed product distributions of hydroisomerization and hydrocracking process are fully discussed by combining the results of molecule size calculations and the intimacy of metal–acid sites. Furthermore, the designed core–shell catalyst serves as a tandem microreactor that can guarantee the shortest path and a single direction for the delivery of guest molecules from the shell (metal sites, dehydrogenation, n-alkenes formation) to the core (acid sites, n-alkenes isomerization or cleavage), and then to the shell (metal sites, hydrogenation, isomeric alkane formation), which provides a novel approach to achieving isomerization or controllable cracking of n-alkanes by finely controlling the distance between the acid sites and metal centers at a nano-scale. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Y zeolite powder (Si/Al = 2.6, S BET = 767 m2/g) was provided from SINOPEC Dalian Research Institute of Petroleum and Petrochemicals Co., Ltd. Isopropanol (99 wt%), ammonia solution (NH3, 25–28 wt%) and tetraethoxysilane (TEOS, 98 wt%) were purchased from Tianjin Kermel Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Cetyl trimethyl-ammonium bromide (CTABr, 99 wt%) was purchased from Shanghai Macklin Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate (H2PtCl6·6H2O, Pt ≥ 37.5 wt%) was purchased from Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. All chemicals with reagent grades were directly used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis 2.2.1 Synthesis of meso-SiO2 support The specific synthesis process is described in our previous work [40]. Typically, 6 g of TEOS was added slowly under vigorous stirring into the mixed liquid (30 mL of isopropanol, 300 mL of deionized water, and 1 g of CTABr). Ammonia solution was added to the system to adjust the pH to 8–9 and stirred at 45 °C for 4 h. The white hydrolysate was filtered, washed, dried at 90 °C overnight, and then calcinated at 550 °C for 4 h with a ramping rate of 2 °C/min under a flow of air to remove the CTABr. The products were collected and labeled as meso-SiO2. 2.2.2 Synthesis of core–shell Y@nSiO2 supports Typically, 2 g Y of zeolite powder and 300 mL of deionized water were mixed together and stirred ultrasonically treatment for 1 h. Subsequently, 30 mL of isopropanol and 1 g of CTABr were successively added and the pH of the solution was adjusted to 8–9 by ammonia water. The aforementioned solution was stirred at 45 °C for 0.5 h. Then, 1–3 g of TEOS was added dropwise under vigorous stirring for 4 h. After filtration, washing, drying, and calcination, the obtained products are denoted as Y@nSiO2, where “n” means the mass ratio of TEOS to Y zeolite. 2.2.3 Preparation of bifunctional catalysts Typically, 2.0 g of Y@nSiO2 was added to 1060 μL of H2PtCl6·6H2O solution (10-2 g/mL), and a moderate amount of water was added to keep the system at an appropriate flow condition. The thick mixture was then sufficiently stirred at 45 °C until the water evaporated nearly completely. The as-obtained solid was calcined at 450 °C for 3 h with a heating rate of 2°C /min in air atmosphere in muffle. For comparison, 0.2Pt/Y, 0.2Pt/Y + S, 0.2Pt/S + Y, and 0.2Pt/(S + Y) were also prepared according to the abovementioned impregnation method. All the catalysts have the same chemical component as 0.2Pt/Y@1S, and the detailed preparation process is seen in the Supporting Information . 2.3 Sample characterization The topological structure of catalysts was recognized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis with a Shimadzu XRD-6000 equipped with Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) and operated at 40 kV and 30 mA with scanning speed 8°/min. N2 adsorption–desorption measurement was performed on a NOVA 1200e gas sorption analyzer. All samples were pre-activated at 300 °C for 3 h, and the measurements were conducted at −196 °C. The specific surface area and micropore surface area were determined utilizing the Brunauer − Emmett − Teller (BET) method and t-plot method, respectively. To assess the distribution of pore sizes, the non-local density functional theory (NLDFT) approach was employed. Morphology of carries was revealed on a scanning electron microscopy (SEM) instrument (Hitachi S-4800) operating at 1 kV and 7 μA. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and TEM-element mapping were recorded on a JEM-2100 operating at 200 kV. Images were acquired in scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) mode by using a high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) detector with a frame time of 20 s. The averaged size of Pt NPs was measured by software Nano Measurer 1.2. The Si/Al ratios and metal content were determined byinductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES; Autoscan16 TJA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted on Thermo Scientifc K-Alpha with Mono AlKα X ray at 1486.6 eV, operating at 12 kV and 6 mA. The energy standard of C1s = 284.80 eV was used for charge correction. Pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy (Py-IR) analysis was performed on a Shimadzu IRAffinity-1 spectrometer to investigate the acidic properties of the samples. The powder sample, approximately 10 mg, was pressed into a thin self-supporting wafer, then its weight was accurately recorded. The wafer was placed in a quartz infrared cellequipped with CaF2 windows and a vacuum system. First, the sample was pretreated in situ under vacuum lower than 10−4 Pa and at 550 °C for 2 h. Second, the samples were adsorbed with pyridine for 10 min at 160 °C, and then evacuated for 30 min at 250, 350, and 450 °C, separately. Finally, the spectrum was recorded at 4 cm−1 resolution. Hydrogen-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out on Micromeritics ASAP 2020C device to test the reduced temperature of Pt species. The tested sample (100 mg) was pre-activated at 350 °C for 2 h to remove water. After cooling it to room temperature, 10 % H2/Ar was added and heated from room temperature to 800 °C, and TCD signal was recorded. H2 chemisorption was also conducted on Micromeritics ASAP 2020C device to test the dispersion of Pt species. The sample was reduced with 10 % H2/Ar at 350 °C for 2 h and then purged in Ar at 350 °C for 1 h. After the temperature was reduced to 30 °C, H2 pulses were injected by a calibrated on-line sampling valve. H2 chemisorption was supposed to be completed until three successive peaks exhibited the same peak areas. The calculation was based on a H2/Pt stoichiometry of 1. 2.4 Catalytic test Catalytic performance for the hydroisomerization of n-alkane was evaluated in a continuous flow fixed-bed reactor. Before reaction, the catalyst was reduced in situ in flow of hydrogen (100 mL/min) at 350 °C for 3 h and later the temperature was adjusted to the desired reaction temperature. n-Alkane was fed into the reactor by high pressure microscale pump, and the hydroisomerization/hydrocracking reactions were carried out in a certain temperature range. Typically, 1 g of catalyst (20–40 meshes) was supported by silica sand quartz wool located in the constant temperature zone of the reactor and the volume ratio of H2/n-alkane was 1000. The weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of n-heptane, n-dodecane, and n-hexadecane was controlled as 4.1, 4.5, and 4.8 h−1, respectively. The products were collected and analyzed by Agilent 8890 gas chromatograph, equipped with an HP-PONA capillary column (50 m × 0.25 mm) and equipped with FID detector. The conversion, selectivity, and yield are calculated from following formulae: (1) Conversion ( % ) = the amount of reactant consumed the amount of reactant in × 100 (2) Selectivity ( % ) = the amount of target products formed the amount of reactant consumed × 100 (3) Yield ( % ) = the amount of target products formed the amount of reactant in × 100 Here, the reactant is n-heptane, n-dodecane or n-hexadecane. 2.5 Adsorption and diffusion kinetics n-Hexane was used as a probe molecule representing linear reactants to investigate diffusion kinetic parameters (D eff/R 2) and diffusion activation energy by the Zero Length Column method (ZLC method) [41]. The ZLC columns were filled with sample weighing approximately 2 mg. The sample was activated overnight at 300 °C in helium (He, 99.99 %, Shanxi Yihong), and cooled to the desired measurement temperature, which corresponds to the linear region of the adsorption isotherm (Henry's Law region). A mix gas of He and n-hexane was introduced into the ZLC column until saturation (40 min), then He flow was used to purge the residual n-hexane gas in the system. The concentration of n-hexane in the effluent was continuously monitored and recorded by gas chromatography (GC), facilitating analysis of effective diffusivity. The flow rate during purging was standardized at 80 mL/min. The effective diffusivity (D eff) was obtained by a long-time analysis method, from the desorption curve described by formula (4): (4) C C 0 = 2 L ∑ n = 1 ∞ exp ( - β n 2 D eff t / R 2 ) β n 2 + L ( L - 1 ) where C 0 and C — the initial and transient effluent concentrations of the probe molecule, respectively; R — the radius of zeolite sample; D eff/R 2 — the effective diffusion time constant. βn in formula (4) can be obtained from formula (5) and formula (6): (5) β n cot β n + l - 1 = 0 (6) L = 1 3 F R 2 K V S D where F — the flow rate of the purge gas; K — the Henry’s constant; V s — the volume of the adsorbent. The diffusion activation energy E a can be obtained by formula (7): (7) E a = R T 2 ∂ ln D eff / R 2 ∂ T 2.6 Intimacy between the acids and metals The required proximity between acids and metals so as to achieve maximum catalytic activity has been quantified as the Weisz Intimacy Criterion [33,42]: (8) r 2 < 1.2 × 10 5 p 0 D T dN dt where 2r (m) — a maximum average distance between the two functions; p 0 (MPa) — the partial pressure of alkenes; T (K) — the reaction temperature; D (m2·s−1) — the diffusivity of alkenes in the sample pores; dN/dt (mol·s−1·m−3) — the reaction rate. 2.7 Thiele modulus The Thiele modulus “ φ ” is used to analyze the effectiveness of intracrystalline diffusion in catalytic reactions. It was derived assuming steady-state diffusion and reaction, a first-order reaction, and isothermal conditions. It is defined as: (9) φ = L k D eff where k (s−1) — the rate constant in the macroscopic kinetic equation of the first-order reaction; D eff (m2·s−1) — the effective diffusion constant; L (m)—the characteristic length of the zeolite particle. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the samples XRD patterns of Y zeolite and as-synthesized Y@nSiO2 (n = 0.5, 1, 1.5) are shown in Fig. 1 A. It is evident that the pristine Y and all the Y@nSiO2 samples exhibit the characteristic diffraction peaks associated with FAU zeolite at 2θ = 6.3°, 10.3°, 15.9°, 20.8°, 24.1°, and 31.4° reflecting (111), (220), (331), (440), (533), and (555) planes, respectively. By increasing the amount of TEOS in synthesis system, the intensity of characteristic diffraction peaks at approximately 6.3°, 15.9°, and 20.8° attributed to the FAU topological structure in the composite samples gradually decrease because the gradually increased amorphous silicon dioxide dilutes the zeolite phase in the composite samples. As shown in Fig. 1B&C, the adsorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the Y@nSiO2 composite samples are different from the pure Y zeolite. It can be seen from Fig. 1B that the Y zeolite displays a typical Type I isotherm, which quickly reaches adsorption saturation at extremely low relative pressure of about 0–0.01 range, reflecting a purely microporous structure. The adsorption isotherm of the composite samples is a combination of type-I and type-IV, indicating the coexistence of micropores and mesopores. The steep increase in the adsorption isotherm within the relative pressure range around 0.2–0.4 would indicate a potentially uniform distribution of mesopore sizes. It can be seen from Fig. 1C that all the Y@nSiO2 composite samples have similar mesopore structure with a pore size distribution centering at about 4 nm, which can be ascribed to the ordered mesopore structure in the SiO2 shell. As shown in Fig. S1, the small-angle XRD pattern of the composite sample exhibits a peak around 2.2°, which is assigned to the (100) surfaces of a 2D hexagonal ordered (111) plane of MCM-41 structure [40,43]. As shown in Table 1 , with the increased mesoporous SiO2 shell, the S BET and S ext of the Y@nSiO2 samples increase gradually while the corresponding S micro and V micro of the samples decline regularly compared with those of the pure Y sample. Fig. 2 depicts the morphology and internal structure of Y and Y@nSiO2 supports. Y zeolite crystal appears as a smooth and well-defined octahedron (Fig. 2A, Fig. S2C) with clear and visible lattice stripes (Fig. 2B), and has a size of about 800–1000 nm. It can be seen from Fig. 2C–H and Fig. S2D that the as-synthesized Y@nSiO2 composite samples have the similar octahedral morphology to the pristine Y zeolite, but the surface becomes rough and furry, and many mesopores can be obviously observed in Fig. S2D. Continuously adding TEOS in initial gel leads to an increase in surface roughness, accompanied by a gradual emergence of discontinuous bulge on the outer surface of the samples. As shown in Fig. 2C, the shell layer is local rupture, reflecting a clear core–shell structure of the as-prepared sample. The SAED results (Fig. S2) reflect that the as-synthesized sample has an amorphous shell and crystalline core. The aforementioned result further confirms that the as-synthesized samples Y@nSiO2 have an obvious core–shell structure. It can be seen from Fig. S3 that the core–shell structured sample has a shell with uniform thickness. Moreover, the TEM images (Fig. 2D, 2F&2H) demonstrate that the shell thickness of the composite samples can be adjusted within a range of approximately 15 to 60 nm by varying the added amount of silicon precursors. Additionally, it is worth noting that there is a limitation on the thickness of the coated layer owing to the gradual reduction in surface tension as particles grow. [40,44,45] The further increased amount of silicon in the gel precursors does not continuously increase the thickness of the shell, but results in the emergence of free silicon micro-spheres (Fig. S4). By combining with Fig. 1A and Fig. S5, it can be observed that after loading Pt species, FAU zeolite keeps its characteristic diffraction almost intact, and shows no any characteristic diffraction peaks of PtO2 (JCPDS 43–1045) in all catalysts, implying a homogeneous dispersion of Pt particles with a low loading amount. In spite of exactly the same amount of Pt-species precursor in the preparation of samples, 0.2Pt/Y + S has the lowest actual Pt content among all of the catalysts (Table 2 ). This may be caused by the un-homogeneous dispersion of Pt species on pure Y zeolite support. The chemical species present on the catalyst surfaces were also assessed by XPS. The most prominent photoemission line of Pt is usually originated from Pt 4f. However, this energy range is overshadowed by the presence of a highly intense Al 2p (as shown in Fig. S6). Consequently, analysis was focused on Pt 4d instead. [46] In Fig. 3 A, two obvious Pt 4d5/2 and 4d3/2 spin splitting peaks can be observed over 0.2Pt/Y + S, and the relative intensity of the two peaks of 0.2Pt/Y + S is stronger than those on 0.2Pt/Y@1S, which seems to contradict the results of ICP-OES (Table 2). XPS is a surface-sensitive technique [47]. One possible explanation is that the Pt species are situated on the external surface of Y zeolite support in 0.2Pt/Y + S, whereas the Pt NPs would be encapsulated inside the core–shell composite 0.2Pt/Y@1S [23,48]. XPS analysis was conducted to further analyze the electronic effects of Pt metal and the carriers. It can be found that the center of Pt 4d3/2 band shifts from 315.3 eV of 0.2Pt/Y@1S to 316.7 eV of 0.2Pt/Y + S, meaning the electron density around Pt species on 0.2Pt/Y@1S increases [49,50]. This also suggests that the Pt-species on 0.2Pt/Y@1S are more likely to gain electrons than those on 0.2Pt/Y + S. It can be observed form Fig. 3B that the O 1 s peak of 0.2Pt/Y@1S is shifted towards higher binding energy (533.0 eV) with respect compared to that of the 0.2Pt/Y + S sample (532.4 eV), which means a decreased electron density around O species. The binding energy of Pt 4d increases with the decrease of O 1 s in core–shell 0.2Pt/Y@1S sample, further implying the charge transfer from O species to Pt NPs. [51] The different Pt species observed at the binding energy of Pt0 (314.02–314.07 eV) and Pt4+ (318.10 eV) [52] were recognized by the XPS database at NIST (National Institute of Standards and Technology by U.S.A.). From these results, it can be concluded that the metallic Pt in 0.2Pt/Y@1S with a partially oxidized state (maybe Pt2+ species) [53] and the core–shell structure of support would also promote the good dispersion of Pt NPs. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) combined with energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) images can expose the cross sections of zeolite crystals and enables the visualization of the spatial distribution of zeolite crystals, SiO2 support, and Pt sites [35,54]. The element mapping shows that the shell layer of 0.2Pt/Y@1S is rich in silicon and Pt species (Fig. 4 D–G). Notably, the outer layer of 0.2Pt/Y@1S catalyst exhibits numerous distinct visible bright spots in Fig. 4A, which can be attributed to the presence of tiny Pt NPs [55]. As shown in Fig. 4C, the distribution of Pt NPs conforms to a normal distribution, with an average diameter of 0.9 nm, slightly larger than the 12-membered rings pore of pure microporous Y zeolite, possibly implying that the majority of Pt NPs exist within the channel of mesoporous SiO2 shell rather than in the microporous channels of Y zeolite. This would ensure the separation of metal sites and zeolite acid sites, achieving controllable distance between the two active sites. As shown in Fig. 5 A&B, most of the Pt NPs in 0.2Pt/S + Y catalyst are supported on mesoporous SiO2 and have a particle size distribution centered around 3.8 nm (Fig. 5B inset), similar to the DFT pore diameter distribution of mesoporous SiO2 phase in the composites (Fig. 1C). This would indicate that most of the Pt NPs are confined in the mesoporous channels of SiO2. Compared with those on the 0.2Pt/S + Y, smaller Pt NPs and higher dispersity of Pt species on 0.2Pt/Y@1S (Fig. 4C, Table 2) can be ascribed to the more external surface area of mesoporous SiO2 in the composite. It can be inferred from Fig. 5C&D that some small Pt NPs with an estimated size of about 3–8 nm exist in the sample 0.2Pt/Y. Fig. 5E&F displays that the loaded Pt species on 0.2Pt/(Y + S) are easier to be dispersed on mesoporous SiO2 rather than on Y zeolite phase. By combining with the results obtained from Fig. 4, it can be speculated that some functional species [52] on Y@1SiO2 or mesoporous SiO2 may have a great influence on the distribution of Pt species. It can be seen from Fig. S7 that compared with Y@1SiO2, 0.2Pt/Y@1S shows a noticeably weakened intensity of band at 3740 cm−1 attributed to silicon terminal hydroxyl groups, suggesting that the loaded Pt-species interact strongly with the silicon terminal hydroxyl groups. The result also shows that the Pt-species are more inclined to load on mesoporous SiO2 than on Y zeolite. As shown in Table 2, the dispersity of Pt-species on the Y is much lower than on the Y@nSiO2 or the mixture support (Y + SiO2), also indirectly reflecting that the Pt-species prefer to deposit on mesoporous SiO2 shell. This would be the main reason that the Pt-species can be highly dispersed on the Y@1SiO2 carrier. Compared with Y zeolite, the mesoporous SiO2 shell with abundant hydroxyl group is an electron-rich body, and its electrons can be transferred to the empty orbital of the Pt species, thus the “strong metal support interactions” (SMSI) is significantly enhanced, promoting the dispersion of Pt on mesoporous SiO2. Consequently, the Pt species tend to be dispersed on mesopore SiO2 rather than on the Y zeolite. The H2-TPR reduction peak of Pt oxides usually locates at the temperature range of 60–260 °C [56]. As shown in Fig. S8, the reduction peak at a lower temperature for the core–shell 0.2Pt/Y@nS catalysts suggests the PtO x species on the composite carriers are easier to be reduced, which is attributed to the well-dispersed Pt species (Table 2). A broad peak centering around 417.6 °C is found on Pt/Y + S, which may be caused by the bulk PtO x species, as observed in Fig. 5C&D. Moreover, a broad peak centering at 369.4 °C can be observed on the sample 0.2Pt/S + Y, which may be resulted from the migration and then agglomeration of Pt-species on the Y zeolite phase during high temperature pre-activation (see Experimental Section). The acidity of Y@nSiO2 support samples was investigated by Py-IR spectra. As shown in Fig. 6 A–C, two distinct IR bands at around 1450 and 1540 cm−1 can be attributed to the adsorption of pyridine on Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, respectively [57,58], and the absorption band at around 1488 cm−1 is caused by the corporate action of Lewis and Brønsted acids [59]. The acid amount of Y, mesoporous SiO2, and Y@nSiO2 was determined by integrating the bands attributed to the Brønsted or Lewis acid sites, as presented in Table 3 . As shown in Fig. 6D, the Brønsted acid sites (160 °C) are in positive correlation with the Y zeolite contained in the as-synthesized samples, revealing regularly varied acidic properties among the different composite carriers. The mesoporous SiO2 shell playing a key role in adjusting the distance between the acid sites and the metal sites in the core–shell composite provides negligible acidic sites. With the increased SiO2 shell in the composite, the concentration of Brønsted acid sites decreases linearly (Fig. 6D). As shown in Fig. S9, 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S displays the similar acidity to Y@0.5SiO2, indicating a slight Pt loading does not significantly alter the acidity of the support. 3.2 Catalytic evaluation 3.2.1 Superimposed effect of diffusion and intimacy at a large scale The impact of intimacy at different scales between metal sites and acid sites on the hydro-isomerization/-cracking of n-dodecane over 0.2Pt/Y + S, 0.2Pt/S + Y, 0.2Pt/Y@1S, and 0.2Pt/S#Y is exhibited in Fig. 7 . The conversion of n-C12 on all the catalysts exhibits a positive correlation with reaction temperature. First, for millimeter-scale catalyst 0.2Pt/S#Y, the distance “L” between the metal and zeolite acid sites is in millimeter-scale (∼2 mm), and the catalyst has an extremely low catalytic activity. The conversion of n-dodecane on 0.2Pt/S#Y is significantly below 10 %, even when the reaction temperatures is up to 316°C. Besides the ratio of metal to acid sites, another critical property of the bifunctional catalysts should be the proximity of both sites to each other. Weisz [33] suggested that there is a maximum distance between both types of sites, beyond which catalytic activity decreases. The normal alkene intermediate has to diffuse from the metal site to the acid site, and the isoalkene intermediate must diffuse the other way. If the distances are too large, concentration gradients develop and catalytic activity also decreases [35]. As depicted in Fig. 7B, the thermal cracking reactions results in a partial conversion rather than isomerization reaction. Because the acid sites and the Pt sites are far from each other, the two catalytic cycles can only communicate in one direction, which is impossible for fulfilling the hydroisomerization process. Moreover, if the distances between metal and acid sites are large, iso-alkenes might undergo secondary reactions, also declining isomer selectivity by giving rise to gas and coke [34,35]. The molecule chain length “l” of n-dodecane can be estimated approximately at 17.69 Å, and the dimensions (length, width, and height) of a molecule are determined by calculating the range between its maximum and minimum coordinates along each axis (Scheme S1). By combining with above results, it can be speculated that the synergistic effect between metal and zeolite acid sites diminishes and even disappears when the “L/l” ratio reaches 1.13 × 106 under the present reaction conditions. Second, by shortening the distance “L” between Pt and zeolite acid sites from millimeter-scale to micrometer-scale, nanometer-scale, and atomic-scale, the catalytic conversion on all the catalysts increases remarkably (Fig. 7A). All the atomic-scale (0.2Pt/Y + S), nano-scale (0.2Pt/Y@1S), and micro-scale (0.2Pt/S + Y) catalysts exhibit well-matched “S-shaped” conversion curves (Fig. 7A) in a temperature range from 210 to 330 °C, which is consistent with what has been reported in the opened literatures [11,25,35]. For the micrometer-scale catalyst 0.2Pt/S + Y, it exhibits a significantly enhanced activity with respect to 0.2Pt/S#Y, with the peak of isomerization yield reaching 28.1 % when the reaction temperature arrives at 297.6 °C (Fig. 7B). The 0.2Pt/S + Y catalyst, with its metal and zeolite acid sites in a closer proximity, exhibits an improved activity and an increased yield of the isomers as compared with 0.2Pt/S#Y. In order to compare the intrinsic catalytic activities of the catalysts during the conversion of n-dodecane, the turnover frequency of Brønsted acid site (TOFacid) and metal site (TOFmetal) were calculated at the conversion < 15 % [60], as Fig. S10A&B shown. By comparing with Fig. 7A, the conformity of TOFacid plot and the inconformity of TOFmetal plot imply that the catalytic activity is closely related to the distribution of Brønsted acid sites [60] and metal sites alone commonly may be not sufficient to represent the activity of bifunctional catalysts in the reaction conditions. Third, as displayed in Fig. 7A, the nanometer-scale catalyst 0.2Pt/Y@1S owns the highest catalytic activity at the same reaction temperature. Although it has a similar isomer yield to 0.2Pt/Y + S at comparable conversion rates (Fig. 7B), 0.2Pt/Y@1S demonstrates a higher catalytic activity at a lower temperature (Fig. 7A). It can be seen from Fig. 7A and Fig. S10C, as n-dodecane conversion is increased from 0 to 100 %, isomers yield gradually increases to reach a maximum value and then decreases as a result of the enhancement of hydrocracking reactions at higher reaction temperatures. The maximum i-C12 yield on 0.2Pt/Y@1S is 50.9 % (267.0 °C), similar to that on 0.2Pt/Y + S (297.7 °C) while much higher than that over 0.2Pt/S + Y (297.7 °C). The areas below the curves for mono-branched, multi-branched isomers, and cracked products overlap observably [61] (Fig. S10D), reflecting that hydrocracking and hydroisomerization are always associated with each other under the present reaction conditions. In addition, the increased branched products also indicate an enhancement in reactivity and a continuous progression of reaction steps [61]. To further demonstrate the important role of the special core–shell structured Y@nSiO2 support in elevating the hydrocracking and hydroisomerization performances of n-dodecane, 0.2Pt/(Y + S) catalyst with a mechanical mixture support of Y and SiO2 was also prepared under the condition that the Pt species, Y, and SiO2 were kept exactly the same to 0.2Pt/Y@1S (see Supporting Information ). It can be inferred that 0.2Pt/Y@1S catalyst exhibits better hydroisomerization performances for an elevated catalytic activity (Fig. S11A) and an increased yield towards to monomethyl and multimethyl isomers (≤270 °C, Fig. S11B&C) than 0.2Pt/(Y + S), and the later has the similar catalytic performances to the 0.2Pt/S + Y catalyst (Fig. 7). It can be seen from Fig. 5 that Pt species in catalyst 0.2Pt/(Y + S) are also observed to be mainly loaded on SiO2 rather than on Y zeolite, similar to Pt/S + Y. 0.2Pt/Y@1S and 0.2Pt/(Y + S) possess similar acid properties but different distance “L” between the acid sites and metal sites. The longer distance “L” will increase the secondary reaction of the formed olefin intermediates during their diffusion between the two active centers. For the core–shell-structured 0.2Pt/Y@1S catalyst, the metal and acid sites are distributed in the shell and the core, respectively. First, the n-alkane is dehydrogenated on the metal site (shell) to form intermediate n-alkene, which then spreads to the acidic site (core) to undergo carbon chain isomerization or cracking. Second, the generated i-alkene diffuses from the acid center (core) to the metal (shell) to achieve hydrogenation and finally form i-alkanes. Obviously, the mass transfer process is from the shell (dehydrogenation, olefin formation) to the core (olefin isomerization or cracking), again to the shell (hydrogenation, iso-alkanes formation) in definite direction. For 0.2Pt/(Y + S) catalyst, the acid center and metal are randomly distributed, and the direction of mass transfer is numerous and uncertain. The length and direction of the transfer path of the formed olefin intermediates (n-alkene or i-alkene) between the two kinds of active center are uncertain, uncontrollable, and easy to cause secondary reactions of the olefin intermediates. As illustrated in Fig. S12, the conversion of n-hexadecane over 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S catalyst exhibits a marginal decline from an initial 60.7 wt% to 57.5 wt% after 65 h reaction at 276 °C. The results indicate that the prepared bifunctional catalysts exhibit negligible deactivation and maintain good stability in the hydro-isomerization/-cracking process. In a word, when the effect of intimacy was investigated by adjusting the location of Pt on mesoporous SiO2, Y zeolite, or the composite carrier Y@SiO2, the catalytic performance of the catalysts may be decided by the superimposed effect of diffusion performance [62], the dispersion and accessibility of Pt sites [11,63]. The catalyst 0.2Pt/Y@1S displays the excellent catalytic performances for a high catalytic activity and high i-C12 yield with a lower reaction temperature because of the special core–shell structure. Besides the dispersion and accessibility of Pt sites, a clear and definite direction of mass transfer from metal to acid and to metal again may also plays a key role. This guarantees that the i-alkenes generated on the acid sites are most likely to meet the metal center (rather than the acid center) in time after leaving the acidic site, and obtain the target product i-dodecane. 3.2.2 Intimacy between bifunctional sites at a nanometer-scale Owing to the lack of nano-scale precision material characterization methods, the “intimacy criterion” was sometime described simply as “the closer the better” [35]. For a long time, this has prevented deeper exploration of the intimacy criterion. A major breakthrough with a description as “the intimacy of the metal and acid sites should be within a nanoscale rather than the closest” in the design of hydrocracking catalyst is suggested by Zečević etal. [35], and the designed catalyst greatly improves the selectivity of hydrocracking process and results in more desired products. The intimacy of the two functional sites within a nanoscale shatters the belief that the metal and acid sites must be as close together as possible for an effective catalysis. In order to more finely explore the effect of affinity between acid sites and Pt sites on the hydro-cracking/-isomerization of n-alkane, a series of core–shell 0.2Pt/Y@nS catalysts with a different shell thickness (∼15 to ∼ 60 nm) were fabricated also. The adjustable thickness of the shell layer mesoporous SiO2 (negligible acidity) within a nanoscale range was utilized to achieve fine regulation of the intimacy between the zeolite acid sites and metal centers. A layer of mesoporous SiO2 shell is coated on the outer surface of zeolite crystal, which is equivalent to constructing a fast mass transfer channel connected with the outer surface of zeolite Y. Obviously, the existence of the mesopore system contributes to diffusional enhancements of guest molecules [63–65] in the Y@nSiO2. In order to verify a good transfer performance of core–shell carriers, n-hexane (with a high saturated vapor pressure) was chosen as a probe molecule to make a comparative study on the diffusion in the core–shell composite and pure Y zeolite, and the results are shown in Fig. S13 and Table 4 . It can be seen from Table 4 that the calculated diffusion activation energy value (E a) is reduced from 59.86 kJ/mol on Y to 57.78, 50.05, and 50.04 kJ/mol on Y@0.5SiO2, Y@1SiO2, and Y@1.5SiO2, respectively, indicating a partially alleviated diffusion energy barrier on the Y@nSiO2 [62]. As shown in Table 4, at 373 K, the effective diffusion coefficient (D eff/R 2) on Y zeolite is 0.0032 s−1. The characteristic diffusion radius R was derived from high-resolution SEM and estimated as about 0.5 μm (Fig. 2), and the D eff of n-hexane in Y zeolite can be calculated as 8 × 10-16 m2·s−1. As a consequence, the average distance of metal and acid for n-alkane conversion has been calculated to be less than 4.04 nm, as tabulated in Table S1 (Formula 8 and the detailed calculations can be found in Supporting Information ) [33,42]. As shown in Fig. 8 A and Fig. S14, the catalytic activity increased with an increased thickness of mesoporous SiO2 shell in the catalysts, even though the total acid content (especially the Brønsted acid content) notably decreases, suggesting that for the hydro-isomerization/-cracking of n-dodecane when the distance “L” of the two active sites is from the atomic scale to nano-scale, the shorter “L”, the lower catalytic activity. On one hand, the diffusion activation energy (E a) follows an order of Y > Y@0.5SiO2 > Y@1SiO2 > Y@1.5SiO2 (Table 4). This means the presence of mesoporous SiO2, which acts as a molecular “highway” [63], is conducive to the diffusion of guest molecules. Iglesia et al. [64,65] assessed the effects of confinement and diffusional limitations on catalytic performances of physical mixtures of Pt/SiO2 with mesoporous Al-MCM-41 and microporous zeolite (FAU, BEA, and MFI) by using isomerization and β-scission of n-heptane as probe reactions. The results displayed that the selectivity on mesoporous Al-MCM-41 depends on bed residence times because of the weak confining interactions by and facile molecular diffusion within the mesopores. While for zeolites, the selectivity of product is decided by intracrystalline residence times. The small pores of zeolites not only stabilize transition states through van der Waals interactions [65] but also hinder molecular diffusion, resulting in the occurrence of secondary transformations of primary alkene products as they egress from the acid domain, before they hydrogenate at extracrystalline metal sites. On the other hand, an ideal catalyst needs to have a balance of metal and acid function. [12] The yield of isomers on 0.2Pt/Y, 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S, and 0.2Pt/Y@1S is nearly identical under similar conversion (Fig. 8B), which can be attributed to the presence of a sufficient number of acid sites, matching the 0.2 % Pt-species impregnation level, that is, an adequate n A/n M ratio. [25,54] Moreover, the diffusion behavior of the formed n-dodecene from the Pt sites to the acid sites may play a vital role in affecting the catalytic performance of the catalyst. Thiele modulus provides an insight into whether the reaction is limited by diffusion or by kinetics. If φ is much less than 1, the reaction is kinetically controlled, and if φ exceeds 1, the reaction is diffusion-limited. [66,67] The calculated φ for n-dodecane hydro-conversion over 0.2Pt/Y and 0.2Pt/Y@1SiO2 are larger than 1.89 and 2.40, respectively (Table S2), indicating a diffusion-limited reaction process (Formula 9 and the detailed calculations see the Supporting Information ). As shown in Fig. 8A, besides 0.2Pt/Y, 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S also displays a lower catalytic activity, further reflecting that the shorter “L” between acid sites and metal sites is not always better [35]. As shown in Fig. S16 , the space between the acid sites and the metal sites can be regarded as a confined box. Here, as the mesoporous channels are identical, the effect of the mesoporous walls on the diffusion behavior of the guest in the catalysts with either a thick shell (a longer “L”) or a thin shell (a shorter “L”) can therefore be uniformly ignored. Fick's first law describes the diffusion of a substance from a high to a low concentration, resulting in a decrease in the concentration gradient and a homogeneous composition. But in fact, substances, which are driven by chemical potential gradient, can also spread from low concentration areas to high concentration areas, and the result of diffusion is to raise the concentration gradient, which is called “reverse diffusion”. In other words, before touching the acid site, alkenes, the intermediate products produced from metal sites, may also have a “reverse diffusion” towards these metal sites owing to the difference in chemical potential, and the final effect of this “reverse diffusion” would be related to the distance between the two sites. In the direction from shell (metal sites) to core (acid sites), for a shorter “L” (for n-C12 on 0.2Pt/Y and 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S, “L/l”≤8.5), the formed n-dodecene may contact metal sites again before contacting the acid sites because of the shorter “L” between the two active sites ( Fig. S16 I). As a consequence, n-dodecane is formed again and may escape from the SiO2 shell, so the catalytic activity of the catalyst as well as the isomerization yield and cracking yield are relatively low. In this case, owing to the shallower depth inserted in the acid centers, mono-branched i-C12 and cleavage products with more carbon atoms would be expected to obtain. For a longer “L” (for n-C12 on 0.2Pt/Y@1.5S, “L/l”= 33.9) ( Fig. S16 II), where, the n-dodecene that leaves from the metal sites can scarcely touch these metal sites again before captured by the acid sites, and might pass through the Y zeolite core. This significantly increases the retention time of guest molecules at the acid sites. In this case, the catalysts may be more active in hydrocracking, and multi-branched i-C12 and cleavage products with lesser carbon atoms would be expected. The experimental results also show that although these catalysts are in the nanoscale range, there is still a significant difference in the actual distance of the two active sites in these catalysts, which will lead to a different catalytic performance. As shown in Fig. S15, the n-heptane conversion rate exhibits an initial increase followed by a decrease with the rising n M/n A ratio of the catalysts, implying a negligible dependence of the conversion on n M/n A ratio in core–shell catalysts. It is observed that the activity is independent of the n M/n A ratio when the ratio is between 0.03 and 0.07 in the work. At this time, the rate-determining steps may be related to acid catalysis [25], transition states [68], and/or the alkene intermediates [7]. Fig. 9 depicts the yields of products with different carbon numbers at various temperatures. All catalysts exhibit a bimodal characteristic. One is the peak with the maximum yield centered around specific temperatures for dodecane isomers. The other is the peak with the highest yield of cracking products centered around varying carbon number and temperature parameters. It can be seen from Fig. 9A, the temperatures of maximum isomerization yield and maximum cracking yield are almost identical, indicating that the hydroisomerization reaction is always accompanied by cracking reaction in 0.2Pt/Y catalyst. As shown in Fig. 9B, the increased yield of isomers at lower temperature may be attributed to the enhanced catalytic activity because of the moderately increased “L” (elevated retention time for the intermediate olefin products at the acid sites) and the more highly-dispersed Pt NPs. In Fig. 9C, it is evident that 0.2Pt/Y@1S demonstrates a higher yield of isomerization with a relatively lower yield of cracking in the low temperature region (260–275°C), while a higher yield of cracking with a lower yield of isomerization in the high temperature stage (280–300°C). The aforementioned results indicate that 0.2Pt/Y@1S catalyst displays controllable hydro-cracking/-isomerization. It can be seen from Fig. 9D that when the distance “L” exceeds ∼ 60 nm (0.2Pt/Y@1.5S), the yield of isomerization decreases significantly while that of cracked products notably increases. The distribution of cracked products on different catalysts differs greatly (270°C). The most active catalyst, 0.2Pt/Y@1.5S, has the lowest isomeric yield and the highest selectivity of cracking products in the final products. As shown in Fig. S17, the main products on 0.2Pt/Y@1.5S are C5–C8, and the corresponding i-C12 is negligible. However, the main cracked product on 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S and 0.2Pt/Y@1S is C11, accompanied with a high yield of corresponding i-C12. These results are in complete agreement with the predictions of the two models previously proposed. As discussed earlier, for a shorter “L” value (for 0.2Pt/Y and 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S, “L/l”≤8.5) ( Fig. S16 I), n-alkene is less likely to pass through Y zeolite crystal, and may have a reverse diffusion and return to the metal sites after contacting with the outer surface Y zeolite core (Scheme 2 , path 2). This results in a relatively low activity while a high i-C12 and C11 yield (Fig. S17, Tables S3-S5) owing to a short retention time at the acid sites; For a larger “L” (for 0.2Pt/Y@1.5S, “L/l” =33.9) ( Fig. S16 II), the olefin intermediates may completely pass through the Y zeolite core (Scheme 2 , path 1). That causes a high catalytic activity, high selectivity for cracked products with fewer carbon atoms, and negligible i-C12 yield (Fig. S17, Table S6) because of a deeply cracking process due to a longer residence time at the acid sites. As shown in Tables S3&S6, with the increase of “L” value, the selectivity ratio of mono-branched chain products to multi-branched ones on the four catalysts gradually decreases. For example, the selectivity of mono-branched i-C12 decreases from 63.07 % on 0.2Pt/Y, to 49.82 % on 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S, to 39.28 % on 0.2Pt/Y@1S, and to 0.51 % on 0.2Pt/Y@1.5S, and the multi-branched chain i-C12 increases from 32.5 % on 0.2Pt/Y, to 35.32 % on 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S, and to 34.11 % on 0.2Pt/Y@1S. This may be caused by the different retention time at the acid sites originated from the different depths of the formed n-dodecene inserted in the acid sites (Y zeolite core) due to the different distance “L” between the Pt sites and the acid sites. 3.2.3 Distance (L) between bifunctional sites to n-alkane molecule chain length (l) Besides n-dodecane, n-hexadecane and n-heptane, respectively standing for a longer and a shorter probe molecule, were also investigated on 0.2Pt/Y and 0.2Pt/Y@nS (n = 0.5;1;1.5) catalysts. It can be seen from Fig. 10 A and Tables S7–S10 that the catalytic activity increases with the increase of shell thickness (“L”), similar to the results in Fig. 8A. Namely, the shorter “L”, the lower activity of the catalysts, and the longer “L” in the nano-scale, the higher catalytic activity. For the longer n-hexadecane, the most active catalyst is still 0.2Pt/Y@1.5S (“L/l” =26.5), further suggesting that a catalyst with a large “L/l” displays a high catalytic activity. As shown in Fig. 10B&C, for the hydro-isomerization/-cracking reaction of n-hexadecane, a shorter “L” in catalyst (for 0.2Pt/Y, and 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S, “L/l”≤6.6) is conducive to isomerization under the condition of a relatively high reaction temperature, while a longer “L” (≥26.5) is in favor of cracking process. It can be inferred from Tables S7–S10 that with the increase of “L/l” value, the selectivity of cracked products increases notably, and the selectivity ratio of mono-branched chain products to multi-branched chain ones decreases dramatically. For example, the selectivity of mono-branched i-C16 decreases from 39.87 % on 0.2Pt/Y, to 7.94 % on 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S, to 4.26 % on 0.2Pt/Y@1S, and the multi-branched chain i-C16 decreases from 5.64 % on 0.2Pt/Y, to 4.76 % on 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S, and that of to 3.68 % on 0.2Pt/Y@1S. The results are similar to the catalytic process of n-dodecane. As shown in Fig. 11 , for the hydro-isomerization/-cracking process of n-heptane with a shorter molecule chain length “l”, the most active catalyst is 0.2Pt/Y@1S (“L/l”=34.8) instead of 0.2Pt/Y@1.5S (“L/l”=52.3), reflecting that a longer “L” between acid sites and metal sites is not always better for the small probe molecule. The abovementioned result also suggests that the intimacy “L” is related with the molecule chain length “l” of n-alkane. It can be seen from Fig. 11A–D, for 0.2Pt/Y, 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S, and 0.2Pt/Y@1S, the similar result can also be obtained: the shorter “L” in the catalyst (such as 0.2Pt/Y and 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S, “L/l” ≤ 13.1), the lower catalytic activity along with the higher selectivity of mono-branched i-C7 (Fig. 11C&D, Table S11), and with a little of cracked products with more carbon atoms (methyl-cyclopentane) can be obtained (Table S11). On the contrary, the longer “L” (34.8≤ “L/l” < 52.3), the higher catalytic activity of the catalyst 0.2Pt/Y@1S accompanied with the relatively lower selectivity of i-C7 while the relatively higher selectivity of cracked products. Fig. 11C&D reflects a similar rule for product distribution despite of different reaction temperatures. More detailed product distribution is shown as Table S11. Under the condition of similar conversion (34 %) of n-heptane, with an increase of “L” value, the selectivity of mono-branched chain products on the three core–shell catalysts gradually decreases, while that of multi-branched chain products gradually increases. For example, the total selectivity of mono-branched i-C7 decreases from 84.49 % on 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S, to 84.07 % on 0.2Pt/Y@1S, and to 77.7 % on 0.2Pt/Y@1.5S, while that of multi-branched chain i-C7 increases from 12.02 % on 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S, to 12.50 % on 0.2Pt/Y@1S, and to 15.61 % on 0.2Pt/Y@1.5S. This agrees with the results of the hydro-isomerization/-cracking of n-dodecane and n-hexadecane very well. The methyl-branching near the terminal carbon of the chain is favored, with about 84.49 % being 2-methylhexane and 3-methylhexane. Moreover, specific isomers are preferentially formed among di-branched isomers. Typical spacing between the methyl groups of di-branched isomers is nearer than two carbon atoms (i.e., 3, 3-dimethylpentane or 2, 3-dimethylpentane) [69–71]. It is interesting that there is no normal alkane generated by cracking process (Table S11 &12), only the i-alkane such as isobutane and methyl-cyclopentane can be detected, which is similar to the results of n-dodecane hydro-isomerization/-cracking conversion (Tables S3-S10). On the basis of the hydro-isomerization/-cracking properties of n-alkanes with different molecular chain lengths on 0.2Pt/Y and core–shell 0.2Pt/Y@nS catalysts, a preliminary quantitative relationship between the molecule chain length “l” of reactant and the distance “L” of metal and acid can be obtained. The catalytic performance of the bi-functional catalysts is determined by the distance “L” of the acid-metal sites and the molecule chain length “l” of the n-alkane. A shorter molecule chain length “l” needs a closer intimacy between the metal sites and the acid sites. And from in an atomic scale to in a nanometer scale, a catalyst with a small “L” is less active, but has a high selectivity towards corresponding i-alkane, especially mono-branched i-alkane. A catalyst with a large “L” has a high hydrocracking activity, more cracked products instead of corresponding i-alkane can be generated. 3.2.4 Reaction process on the bifunctional catalyst In the light of the general mechanism of n-alkane hydroconversion over meta-acid bifunctional catalysts, the metal phase performs only hydrogenation–dehydrogenation reactions, while isomerization and cracking reactions are catalyzed exclusively by acid sites, alkenes and carbocations are involved as intermediates [3]. Scheme 2 is a schematic diagram representing the hydro-cracking/-isomerization process observed on the bi-functional catalysts, in which initial dehydrogenation of n-alkanes occurs at the metal sites, resulting in the formation of n-alkenes. Subsequently, n-alkenes are captured by the acid sites and then protonated. When the “L/l” (≤13.1) ratio is small for example, the hydro-cracking/-isomerization process of n-dodecane, n-hexadecane, or n-heptane on catalysts 0.2Pt/Y, 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S ( Table S13 , green), the formed n-alkene may contact other metal sites again when it is transported from the metal sites to the acid sites (a shorter retention time at the acid sites). As a consequence, the corresponding n-alkane can be generated again, so the catalytic activity of the catalyst as well as the isomerization and cracking yields are relatively low. Higher selectivity towards mono-branched i-alkane and cracked products with more carbon atoms can be obtained. When the “L/l” (52.3 > L/l ≥ 26.5) ratio is large enough, such as the hydro-cracking/-isomerization process of n-dodecane or n-hexadecane on catalysts 0.2Pt/Y@1.5S, n-heptane on 0.2Pt/Y@1S ( Table S13 , blue), the formed n-alkene leaving the metal sites can scarcely touch the metal sites again before captured by the acid sites and will stay a longer time at the acid sites. Consequently, the catalysts may be more active in hydrocracking, and more cleavage products with lesser carbon atoms can be expected. When the “L/l” further increases, for example the hydro-cracking/-isomerization process of n-heptane on catalyst 0.2Pt/Y@1.5S (L/l ≥ 52.3), the catalytic activity decrease significantly. For the design of the bifunctional catalyst applied in hydro-isomerization/-cracking process, the distance “L” between the metal sites and the acid sites must match with the molecule chain length “l” of the targeted reactant n-alkane, and a relatively small “L/l” ratio is in favor of hydroisomerization while a large “L/l” ratio contributes to a hydrocracking process. In the as-designed core–shell 0.2Pt/Y@nS catalyst, the distance between the acid sites and metal sites can be adjusted in a nanoscale, a clear and definite direction of mass transfer from metal to acid, and to metal can play a role in controlling the reaction process. The mass transfer process of reactant from the shell (metal sites, dehydrogenation, n-alkenes formation) to the core (acid sites, n-alkenes isomerization or cleavage), and then to the shell (metal sites, hydrogenation, isomeric alkane formation) fits perfectly with the hydro-isomerization/-cracking mechanism. 4 Conclusions In the present work, a series of catalysts with different intimacy (in atomic, nanosized, micron, and millimeter scales) between acids and metals were designed and prepared. In particular, Y@nSiO2 core–shell composites with adjustable shell thickness at nanometer scale (15–60 nm) were synthesized. Here, the acid-free mesoporous SiO2 shell not only played a crucial role in trapping and promoting highly dispersed Pt nanoparticles, but also finely regulated the distance (“L”) between the acid sites and the metal sites at the nanometer-scale, thus contributing to an in-depth investigation on the effect of the spatial relationship between the metal and acid sites on the hydro-cracking/-isomerization of n-alkanes. XRD, N2 adsorption–desorption, and SEM/TEM results displayed a layer of 15–60 nm mesoporous SiO2 shell overgrown on the outer surface of Y zeolite by controlling the hydrolysis of ethyl orthosilicate. ZLC tests showed that the mesoporous silica constructs a layer of fast mass transfer channel on the outer surface of Y zeolite, and H2-TPR and XPS measurements exhibited that the mesoporous SiO2 improves the high dispersion of Pt nanoparticle. DRIFT spectra and TEM observations confirmed Pt species are more likely to be loaded on the surface of mesoporous silica by binding with hydroxyl group. HAADF-STEM and Element mapping results indicated that the loaded Pt nanoparticles are mainly distributed near the outer surface of mesoporous silica. The results of hydro-cracking/-isomerization of n-heptane, n-dodecane, and n-hexadecane with different molecule chain length “l” reflected that the distance “L” between the metal and the acid sites is necessarily neither too far nor too close. By shortening the distance “L” between Pt and zeolite acid sites from millimeter-scale to micrometer-scale, nanometer-scale, and atomic-scale, the catalytic activity on all the catalysts increases rapidly. For the catalyst with the intimacy of “L” in a nanoscale, when the L/l ratio was small (≤13.1), the catalyst displayed a relatively low catalytic activity while a high selectivity towards corresponding i-alkane. A large L/l (26.5 ≤ L/l < 52.3) ratio offered the catalysts with a high hydrocracking activity while a low selectivity for i-alkane. When L/l was larger than 52.3 in the present work, the catalytic activity of the catalyst obviously decreased. Moreover, with the increased L/l ratio, more cracked products with fewer carbon atoms were generated, and the selectivity ratio of mono-branched products to multi-branched chain products decreased notably, and vice versa. The core–shell structured catalysts coated with a SiO2 shell demonstrate a controllable catalytic cracking and isomerization by controlling the thickness of SiO2 shell. By varying the degree of proximity between the two components within the bifunctional catalysts, valuable insights into how spatial arrangement influences their effectiveness can be realized. This systematic approach allows us to evaluate not only their catalytic activity but also their product selectivity under optimized reaction conditions mentioned earlier. Furthermore, the commendable catalytic stability observed in core–shell catalysts warrants further investigation to elucidate their potential value. coredata.dc:description: Owing to the important industrial value in hydro-isomerization/-cracking process, metal–acid bifunctional catalysts have attracted much attention. However, exploring the spatial distance namely the intimacy between the two active components remains a primary challenge in the development of a bifunctional catalytic system, as there are limited synthesis protocols for rationally organizing the two components to maximize the synergistic effect. Herein, a series of catalysts with different degrees of intimacy were prepared, which can be assorted into four scales: atomic-, nanometer-, µm-, and millimeter-scale. Specially, Pt/Y@nS core–shell composite with an adjustable shell thickness in a nanometer scale (∼15 to ∼ 60 nm) was designed and synthesized. Not only playing a crucial role in confining and promoting highly dispersed Pt nanoparticles, the acid-free mesoporous SiO2 shell also finely regulates the distance (“L”) between acids and metals in a nanoscale, thereby facilitating a deep investigation into the spatial relationship between metals and acid sites. Three n-alkanes (n-heptane, n-dodecane, and n-hexadecane) with a different molecular chain length (“l”) were selected as probe molecules so as to investigate the effect of “L/l” ratio on the hydro-isomerization/-cracking reaction. The results indicated that a relatively small L/l (≤13.1) ratio is not in favor of the conversion of the alkane molecules, for example, the hydro-cracking/-isomerization process of n-dodecane, n-hexadecane, or n-heptane on 0.2Pt/Y, 0.2Pt/Y@0.5S. A smaller L/l ratio offers the catalyst with a low catalytic activity, here, isomerization and cracking yields are low. High selectivity towards mono-branched i-alkane accompanied with a little of cracked products with more carbon atoms can be obtained. On the contrary, a relatively large L/l (52.3 > L/l ≥ 26.5) ratio in the catalyst contributes to elevating the catalytic activity, for example, the hydro-cracking/-isomerization process of n-dodecane or n-hexadecane on catalysts 0.2Pt/Y@1.5S, n-heptane on 0.2Pt/Y@1S. A larger L/l ratio gives the catalyst a higher activity in hydrocracking, in which more cleavage products with lesser carbon atoms can be obtained, and with an enhanced L/l ratio, the selectivity towards corresponding i-alkane along with the selectivity ratio of mono-branched i-alkanes to multi-branched ones in the final products decreases significantly.
